div.div: Jadranska banka je bila ustanovljena na občnem zboru v prostorih Slovanske čitalnice v Narodnem domu v Trstu v nedeljo, 29. oktobra 1905. Od tega dne naprej je Jadranska banka predstavljala denarni zavod velikega pomena za slovenski gospodarski svet , saj predstavlja drugo slovensko bančno ustanovo, pred njo je leta 1900 bila ustanovljena le še Ljubljanska kreditna banka. Delnice so odkupili slovenski in hrvaški denarni zavodi, pri odkupu pa so se jim pridružili tudi vidni gospodarstveniki in politiki. Prvi upravni svet banke, ki je štel enajst članov, so sestavljali: vitez Ante Vuković, državni poslanec in posestnik iz Trsta (predsednik), dr. Gustav Gregorin, odvetnik iz Trsta (podpredsednik), Ante Bogdanović, trgovec iz Trsta, vitez Tomaž Cossovich, tržaški ladjar, dr. Radoslav Kvekić, državni poslanec in odvetnik v Trstu, Ivan Gorjup, veljak Edinosti in posestnik na Opčinah pri Trstu, Gracijan Stepančič, trgovec iz Trsta, dr. Fran Urbanić, profesor v Zagrebu, Ivan Hribar, slovenski politik in ljubljanski župan, Tomaž Stipanović, ravnatelj banke na Reki (Rijeka) in Ladislav Pečanka, ravnatelj banke v Ljubljani. Poleg osnovnega bančnega poslovanja so upravitelji Jadranske banke igrali veliko vlogo v gospodarskem življenju in preko banke širili svoje interese: posegali so v špedicijske posle (Trgovska in špedicijska družba Balkan), industrijo (Pivovarna Adria v Senožečah), pomorstvo (Paroplovna družba Dalmatia, Delniška ladjarska družba Oceania) in zavarovalništvo (Zavarovalnica Atlanta). Skupaj s Tržaško posojilnico in hranilnico ter Trgovsko-obrtno zadrugo je Jadranska banka ustanovila Hotelsko delniško družbo Grljan-Miramar. Do izbruha prve svetovne vojne je Jadranska banka razširila mrežo svojih podružnic, te so bile v Opatiji, Ljubljani, Kotorju, Metkovićih, Dubrovniku, Zadru, Splitu, Šibeniku in tudi na Dunaju. Po koncu prve svetovne vojne se je banka razdelila na dvoje, saj je velik del ozemlja, na katerem je delovala, pripadel Kraljevini Italiji, obstala pa je tudi bančna ustanova na jugoslovanskem ozemlju. V Jugoslaviji je banka poslovala vse do začetka druge svetovne vojne, v Italiji pa je leta 1923 najprej prišlo do nacionalizacije (banko so večinsko prevzele italijanske banke), nato pa do zloma v letu 1927. Jadranska banka je v Trstu poslovala dobrih dvajset let in na tem prostoru pustila močan pečat. V času pred prvo svetovno vojno lahko opazujemo podobo izredno uspešne banke, ki se je uveljavila ne samo v Trstu, temveč tudi na Hrvaškem in v Dalmaciji, svoje interese pa je širila v samo osrčje avstroogrske monarhije. Povojna leta banki niso bila naklonjena, saj je poslovala v nenormalnih razmerah, ki so bile uperjene proti slovenskim inštitucijam, s tem pa tudi proti enemu izmed stebrov slovenske prisotnosti v tedanji Julijski krajini, Jadranski banki. Milan Pahor

Jadranska banka (Adriatic Bank) was established at the general meeting in the facilities of the Slavic Reading Club (Slovanska čitalnica) in the National Hall in Trieste on Sunday, 29 October 1905. Since that day Adriatic Bank was a monetary institution of extraordinary importance for the Slovenian economic world, as it represented the second Slovenian banking institution (only the Ljubljanska kreditna banka – Credit Bank of Ljubljana – had been established before it, in 1900). The stock was bought by Slovenian and Croatian monetary institutions as well as prominent businessmen and politicians. The first management board of the bank consisted of the following eleven members: Sir Ante Vuković, member of parliament and proprietor from Trieste (president); Dr. Gustav Gregorin, attorney from Trieste (vice president); Ante Bogdanović, merchant from Trieste; Sir Tomaž Cossovich, ship owner from Trieste; Dr. Radoslav Kvekić, member of parliament and attorney in Trieste; Ivan Gorjup, prominent member of the Edinost (Unity) political society and proprietor in Opicina near Trieste; Gracijan Stepančič, merchant from Trieste; Dr. Fran Urbanić, professor in Zagreb; Ivan Hribar, Slovenian politician and mayor of Ljubljana; Tomaž Stipanović, bank manager in Rijeka; and Ladislav Pečanka, bank manager in Ljubljana. Besides focusing on the main banking business, the managers of the Adriatic Bank also played a major role in the economic life and furthered their interests through the bank: they were involved in the forwarding agency business (Trgovska in špedicijska družba Balkan – Balkan Commerce and Forwarding Company), industry (Pivovarna Adria – the Adria Brewery in Senožeče), shipping (Paroplovna družba Dalmatia – Dalmatia Steam Shipping Company; Delniška ladjarska družba Oceania – Oceania Joint Stock Shipping Company) and insurance business (Zavarovalnica Atlanta – Atlanta Insurance Company). Together with the Trieste Loan and Savings Bank (Tržaška posojilnica in hranilnica) and Trade and Craft Cooperative (Trgovsko-obrtna zadruga) the Adriatic Bank founded the Grljan-Miramar hotel joint stock company. Until the beginning of World War I the Adriatic Bank had expanded the network of its branches to Opatija, Ljubljana, Kotor, Metkovići, Dubrovnik, Zadar, Split, Šibenik, as well as Vienna. After the end of World War I the bank was divided into two parts, since a large part of the territory it operated on was annexed to the Kingdom of Italy, while it kept operating as a banking institution in the Yugoslav territory as well. In Yugoslavia it kept operating until as late as the beginning of World War II, while in Italy it was first nationalised (the majority share was taken over by Italian banks) and then dissolved in 1927. In Trieste the Adriatic Bank operated for more than twenty years and left a strong mark in this region. Before World War I it was an exceedingly successful bank, which did not only assert itself in Trieste, but also in Croatia in Dalmatia, while it expanded its interests into the very heart of the Austro Hungarian Monarchy. However, the post war years were hard for this bank, since it had to conduct its business in abnormal circumstances, stacked against Slovenian institutions and thus also against one of the pillars of the Slovenian presence in what was then Venezia Giulia: the Adriatic Bank. Milan Pahor

Leta 1909 je bil v okviru hrvaške skupnosti v Trstu ustanovljen denarni zavod z imenom Hrvatska štedionica – registrovana zadruga z ograničenim jamstvom. Zamisel o osnovanju lastnega denarnega zavoda je padla na plodna tla, saj je po dveh letih zadruga štela že preko 400 članov. Štedionica je poslovala v strogem središču mesta, v prvem nadstropju stavbe na Borznem trgu št. 3. V času njenega delovanja so se člani denarnega zavoda sestali na enajstih letnih skupščinah. Na prvi so hranilnico ustanovili, nato je pa sledilo devet rednih občnih zborov, na izrednem enajstem pa so člani sami razpustili denarni zavod. Prvi redni občni zbor se je odvijal 3. aprila 1910, drugi 26. marca 1911, tretji 24. marca 1912, četrti 26. marca 1913, peti 29. marca 1915, šesti 18. avgusta 1917, sedmi 2. novembra 1920, osmi 8. junija 1921 in deveti 8. junija 1922. Izbruh prve svetovne vojne je močno prizadel poslovanje hrvaškega denarnega zavoda, težave pa so sledile tudi v času povojne obnove, saj je po razpadu avstrogrske monarhije Trst pripadel Kraljevini Italiji. Zloglasnega 13. julija 1920 so fašistične škvadre poleg tržaškega Narodnega doma napadle še druge cilje, med njimi je bil tudi sedež Hrvatske štedionice na Borznem trgu. Iz previdnosti so člani na občnem zboru leta 1920 prilagodili naziv, Hrvatska štedionica se je preimenovala v Zadružno štedionico oz. v italijanskem prevodu Cassa di risparmio federale. S tem dejanjem je iz imena banke izginila narodnostna oznaka. Pritisk italijanskih bančnih oblasti pa je kljub temu bil prehud in je oviral normalno poslovanje. V težkih okoliščinah so se zadružniki 7. novembra 1922 še zadnjič zbrali na izredni skupščini ter se odločili za likvidacijo. S tem dejanjem so se izognili nasilnemu podržavljenju denarnega zavoda in s tem odvzemu premoženja dejanskim hrvaškim lastnikom. Ob razpustu je Hrvatska štedionica štela 612 članov, na mestu predsednika pa so se v 13 letih obstoja hranilnice zvrstili Ljubomir Tomašić, Ivo Antičević, Milan Marušić in Ivo Randić. Milan Pahor

In 1909 a monetary institution named "Hrvatska štedionica – registrovana zadruga z ograničenim jamstvom" (Croatian Savings Bank – registered cooperative with limited liability) was established by the Croatian community in Trieste. The idea of establishing a Croatian monetary institution was well received, since after two years the cooperative already had more than 400 members. The Croatian Savings Bank operated in the very centre of the city, on the first floor of a building on Piazza della Borsa 3 square. During its active period its members met at eleven annual general assemblies. The savings bang was founded at the first assembly, after which nine regular general meetings took place, while at the extraordinary eleventh assembly the monetary institution was disbanded by the members themselves. The first regular general meeting took place on 3 April 1910, the second on 26 March 2011, the third on 24 March 1912, the fourth on 26 March 1913, the fifth on 29 March 1915, the sixth on 18 August 1917, the seventh on 2 November 1920, the eight on 8 June 1921, and the ninth meeting took place on 8 June 1922. The outbreak of World War I strongly affected the business operations of the Croatian monetary institution. The period of the post war restoration was also problematic, since after the dissolution of the Austro Hungarian Monarchy, Trieste was annexed to the Kingdom of Italy. On the infamous day of 13 July 1920 the fascists attacked the National Hall in Trieste as well as other targets, among them the head office of the Croatian Savings Bank at the Piazza della Borsa square. Out of caution, at the general meeting in 1920 the members adapted the name: Croatian Savings Bank was renamed as a Cooperative Savings Bank (Zadružna štedionica), or, in the Italian translation, Cassa di risparmio federale. Thus the national reference disappeared from the name of the bank. Nevertheless, the pressure from the Italian banking authorities was too severe, hindering normal business operations. In these difficult circumstances the members of the cooperative gathered one last time on 7 November 1922 at an extraordinary assembly and decided to liquidate the institution. In this way they avoided the forced nationalisation of the monetary institution and the consequent confiscation of property from the actual Croatian owners. When it was dissolved, the Croatian Savings Bank had 612 members. During its 13 years of existence the institution was presided over by Ljubomir Tomašić, Ivo Antičević, Milan Marušić and Ivo Randić. Milan Pahor

Ustanovni občni zbor Slovenske čitalnice v Škednju (v predmestju Trsta) je bil 17. junija 1897 v gostilni Gašperja Sancina. Tam je nato Slovenska čitalnica (včasih zapisana tudi kot Slovanska čitalnica) delovala dve leti, saj je imela na razpolago dvorano v prvem nadstropju nad gostilno. V maju 1899 se je preselila v hišo Mihaela Sancina pred cerkvijo, kjer je imelo svoje prostore Gospodarsko društvo. Čitalnica je imela na razpolago eno sobo. Leta 1903 je Gospodarsko društvo kupilo stavbo, ki je postala sedež zadruge. Tja se je 1. februarja 1903 preselila tudi Slovenska čitalnica, kjer je nato ostala vse do nasilnega razpusta v letu 1927. Glavni pobudnik za ustanovitev nove čitalnice v Škednju je bil učitelj in gospodarstvenik Drago Godina, ki je postal tudi prvi predsednik čitalnice. Ostali predsedniki so bili še Lovrenc Flego, Benedikt Godina in Srečko Šuman. Glavna skrb je bila nakup knjig za čitalnico in pridobivanje novih članov. Tako je v prvih petih letih delovanja čitalnica štela okrog 100 članov in nakupila (ali drugače pridobila) okrog 700 knjig. Čitalnica je bila naročena tudi na številne slovenske in hrvaške knjige ter na knjižne zbirke Slovenske matice, Mohorjeve družbe in Matice Hrvatske. V sklopu čitalnice je delovala tamburaška skupina. Višek delovanja Slovenske čitalnice je bil v letih 1904-1914. Prva vojna vihra je delovanje seveda ohromila. Po vojni je čitalnica zaživela, vendar je bil pritisk oblasti viden pri vsakem koraku. Delovanje čitalnice je bilo otežkočeno in stalno pod vprašajem, dokler ni bila nasilno razpuščena z odlokom fašističnih oblasti v letu 1927.Milan Pahor

The founding general meeting of Slovenska čitalnica (Slovenian Reading Club) in Servola (in the Trieste suburbs) took place on 17 June 1897 in Gašper Sancin's tavern. There the Slovenian Reading Club (sometimes also referred to as "Slovanska čitalnica" – "Slavic Reading Club") remained active for two years, as it had the hall in the first floor (over the tavern) at its disposal. In May 1899 the Club was relocated to Mihael Sancin's house next to the church, where Gospodarsko društvo (Economic Society) also had its facilities. The Reading Club had one room at its disposal. In 1903 the Economic Society bought a building, which became the registered office of the cooperative. On 1 February 1903 the Slovenian Reading Club also moved to the new building and remained there until its forced dissolution in 1927. The main initiator for the establishment of the new reading club in Servola was the teacher and businessman Drago Godina, who also became its first president. Apart from him, the Club was also presided over by Lovrenc Flego, Benedikt Godina and Srečko Šuman. The main concern of the Slovenian Reading Club was the purchase of books and acquisition of new members. Thus in the first five years of its activities the Club had around 100 members, and it bought (or acquired in another manner) around 700 books. Slovenian Reading Club also subscribed to numerous Slovenian and Croatian book collections as well as to collections of the Slovenska matica, Mohorjeva družba and Matica Hrvatske publishing houses. A tamburica ensemble also operated in the context of the Club. Slovenian Reading Club reached the peak of its activities in the years between 1904 and 1914. Naturally, World War I brought them to a halt. After the war the Reading Club came back to life, but the pressure exerted by the authorities was evident at every step. Its activities were made difficult and its very existence was constantly questionable, until it was dissolved forcedly with the decree of the fascist authorities in 1927. Milan Pahor

Dne 29. januarja 1861 so tržaški Slovenci z ostalimi v mestu živečimi Slovani ustanovili društvo z imenom Slavjanska narodna čitalnica. Na ustanovnem občnem zboru so bili ob Slovencih prisotni Hrvati, Srbi, Črnogorci, Čehi, Poljaki in Slovaki. 9. marca 1861 je sledilo še odprtje sedeža v drugem nadstropju Brigidove hiše, danes Ulica Pozzo del Mare štev. 1. Društveni prostori so bili odprti vsak dan. Člani so prebirali časopise in revije ali igrali biljard. Ob tem so seveda govorili o političnih, kulturnih, narodnih in drugih dogodkih. Tako je čitalnica opravljala pomembno vlogo kot središče družbenega, družabnega in kulturnega življenja tedanjih meščanov slovanskega rodu v mestu. Nastajalo je slovensko in slovansko meščanstvo v mestu ob Jadranskem morju. Vodstvo čitalnice je od časa do časa prirejalo kulturne prireditve: Kulturne večere, čajanke, plese, tečaje (slovenskega, hrvatskega in češkega jezika), zahvalne maše, izlete. Prvih šestdeset let delovanja (1861-1920) je Slavjanska čitalnica domovala v Ulici Pozzo del Mare, nato na Velikem trgu, v Novi ulici (danes Ulica Mazzini), pa v Ulici Molin piccolo, v Ulici sv. Frančiška štev. 2, leta 1904 pa se je preselila v prvo nadstropje Narodnega doma v Trstu. V glavnem je Slavjanska čitalnica vedno domovala v bližini ostalih osrednjih slovenskih ustanov iz narodnjaškega kroga Edinosti. Ustanova je od samega začetka štela veliko članov.Od same ustanovitve dalje je v čitalnici deloval Franc Cegnar (1826-1892), ki je bil med soustanovitelji in dolgoletni tajnik društva, bil pa je poznan tudi kot pesnik in prevajalec. Močno sled je v ustanovi pustil tudi Ivan Dolenc (1840-1880), ki je bil med pobudniki ustanovitve Političnega društva Edinost in nato istoimenskega lista. V vrstah čitalnice so bili med drugimi: Lesni trgovec Josip Mankoč, trgovci Nikola in Luka Tripković, brodar Mate Polić, Krsto Opnić, Josip Zorman, veleposestnik Franc Kalister, veleposestnik Josip Gorup, pevovodji Ivan Dolinar in Anton Hajdrih, zdravnik Simon Pertot, zdravnik Fran Mandić, njegov brat Matko Mandić, duhovnik in poslanec, ter mnogo drugih. Iz poročila ob 50-letnici Slovanske čitalnice, kot so pozneje pravili prvotni Slavjanski čitalnici (1861-1911), izvemo, da je bila čitalnica naročena na 110 časopisov in revij (22 slovenskih, 36 čeških, 17 hrvaških, 5 srbskih, 5 italijanskih, 2 francoska, 22 nemških in 1 angleški). Ob 50-letnici je ustanova štela 220 članov. Na slovesnosti ob petdesetletnici so ji čestitali med drugimi: Lazar Aničić, predsednik Srpske čitaonice v Trstu, Krsto Krstulović, predsednik Dalmatinaskega skupa v Trstu, Anton Zahorsky, predsednik Češke besede v Trstu…Po zaključku prve svetovne vojne in po prihodu Kraljevine Italije v Trst so se razmere spremenile. Obujeno delovanje Slovanske čitalnice je nasilno in kruto prekinil fašistični požig Narodnega doma dne 13. julija 1920. Čitalnica je bila uničena in z njo so zgorele knjige, časopisi in revije. S požigom je bila uničena slovenska in slovanska duša, ki je takrat resnično živela in žarela v mestu v zalivu. Milan Pahor

On 29 January 1861 the Trieste Slovenians and other Slavs living in this city founded a society named Slavjanska narodna čitalnica (Slavic National Reading Club). Apart from Slovenians, Croats, Serbs, Montenegrins, Checks, Poles and Slovaks also attended the founding general meeting. On 9 March 1861 the opening of a registered office in the second floor of the Brigido house, today Pozzo del Mare 1 street, took place. The society's premises were open every day. Its members leafed through newspapers and magazines and shot pool. Naturally, while doing that they also discussed the political, cultural, national and other events. Thus the reading club had an important role as a centre of the societal, social and cultural life of the citizens of Slavic origin living in Trieste at the time. Thus Slovenian and Slavic bourgeoisie formed in a city by the Adriatic Sea. Occasionally the management of the reading club would organise cultural events: cultural evenings, tea parties, dances, courses in the Slovenian, Croatian and Czech language, masses, and excursions. For the first sixty years of its activities (1861-1920) the Slavic National Reading Club was located in the Pozzo del Mare street. Then it moved to the Piazza Grande square, to the via Nuova street (today via Mazzini street), to the Molin piccolo street, via San Francesco 2 street, and finally to the first floor of the National Hall in Trieste. Most of the time the Slavic Reading Club was located near the other important Slovenian institutions from the Edinost patriotic circle. Ever since the beginning it boasted a large number of members.Since the very establishment of the Slavic Reading Club, Franc Cegnar (1826-1892) took part in it. Also known as a poet and translator, he was among its co founders and for many years he was also its secretary. Ivan Dolenc (1840-1880) also left a strong mark: he was among the initiators of the Edinost (Unity) political society and the gazette with the same name. Among others, the ranks of the Reading Club members also included: wood merchant Josip Mankoč, merchants Nikola and Luka Tripković, ship owner Mate Polić, Krsto Opnić, Josip Zorman, landowner Franc Kalister, landowner Josip Gorup, choirmasters Ivan Dolinar and Anton Hajdrih, doctor Simon Pertot, doctor Fran Mandić, his brother, a priest and member of parliament Matko Mandić, and many others. The report drawn up at the 50th anniversary of Slovanska čitalnica (Slavic Reading Club), which was also what the society was called after the initial "Slavjanska čitalnica" (1861-1911), indicated that the club subscribed to 110 newspapers and magazines (22 Slovenian, 36 Czech, 17 Croatian, 5 Serbian, 5 Italian, 2 French, 22 German and 1 British). At its 50th anniversary the society had 220 members. At this occasion it was congratulated by the following people, among others: Lazar Aničić, president of Srpska čitaonica (Serbian Reading Club) in Trieste; Krsto Krstulović, president of Dalmatinski skup (Dalmatian Society) in Trieste; Anton Zahorsky, president of Češka beseda (Czech Word) in Trieste; etc. However, after the end of World War I and the annexation of Trieste to the Kingdom of Italy, the circumstances changed. The restored activities of the Slavic Reading Club came to a violent and cruel end as the fascists burned down the National Hall on 13 July 1920. The Reading Club and its books, newspapers and magazines were destroyed. The arson destroyed the Slovenian and Slavic soul, truly alive and vibrant in the city by the sea before then. Milan Pahor

Pevsko društvo Adrija je bilo ustanovljeno leta 1889 v hiši Jožka Žnidarja v Barkovljah v Trstu. Tam je bil tudi prvi sedež društva, ki si je nato priskrbelo lastni sedež v prostorih domačega Obrtnijskega društva. Prvi pevovodja zbora Adrija je bil Hrabroslav Ražem (1863-1908), po rodu iz Bazovice. Zbor Adrija se je v bistvu razvil iz cekvenega zbora, pevovodja Ražem je bil tudi organist. Ob glavni skrbi za zbor je vodstvo društva razvilo še drugo dejavnost, saj je prirejalo veselice, plesne venčke, pustne plese, izlete, srečolove ipd. Svojo desetletnico so Adrijaši proslavili 9. in 10. julija 1899. Takrat so razvili svoj društveni prapor. Po pevodju Ražmu so zbor do prve svetovne vojne vodili še Anton Grbec (1878-1906) in domačin Ferdinand Pertot , nato pa še Vladimir Premru (1880-1929). Pevsko društvo Adrija je svečano proslavilo tudi 25-letnico delovanja in sicer 7. junija 1914. Prva svetovna vojna je ohromila bogato delovanje društva, saj je marsikateri pevec moral služiti avstroogrsko vojsko. Po zaključku vojne je zbor najprej prevzel študent Franc Stipolšek, nato pa domači učitelj Viktor Čermelj (1899-1953). Leta 1920 je pevski zbor Adrija prevzel pevovodja, domačin in učitelj Milan Pertot (190-1967), ki je vodil Adrijaše vse do nasilnega razpusta društva v septembru 1927. Pred tem so se fašistične škvadre že izkazale svoje namene, ko so 12. decembra 1921 zažgali Narodni dom v Barkovljah. Ob pevskem zboru je v društvu Adrija nekaj let deloval tamburaški ansambel. Prav tako je bil uspešen dramski odsek. Skratka, septembra 1927 je bilo nasilno prekinjeno bogato slovensko kulturno delovanje v Barkovljah. Vse to je lahko oživelo šele po osvoboditvi v maju 1945. Milan Pahor

div.pre: The Adria Choir Society (Pevsko društvo Adrija) was founded in 1889 in Jožko Žnidar's house in Barcola, Trieste. Initially the registered office of the society was also located there, but soon the society got its own premises in the local Craft Association (Obrtnijsko društvo). The first choirmaster of the Adria Choir was Hrabroslav Ražem (1863-1908) from Basovizza. Essentially Adria Choir had developed from a church choir, and choirmaster Ražem was also an organist. Apart from managing the choir, the society also pursued other activities: it organised festivities, dances, Shrovetide dances, excursions, raffles, etc. The members of the Adria Choir celebrated their tenth anniversary on 9 and 10 July 1899. At that occasion they also raised their society's banner. After choirmaster Ražem, before World War I, the choir was also led by Anton Grbec (1878-1906), Ferdinand Pertot, a local, and Vladimir Premru (1880-1929). On 7 June 1914 Adria Choir celebrated its 25th anniversary. However, World War I brought its activities to a halt, as many singers had to serve in the Austro Hungarian Army. After the end of the war the choir was first taken over by the student Franc Stipolšek, and then by the local teacher Viktor Čermelj (1899-1953). In 1920 Adria Choir was taken over by the local choirmaster and teacher Milan Pertot (1900-1967), who led the Adria Choir until the forced dissolution of the society in September 1927. By then the fascists had already proved their intentions by burning the National Hall in Barcola on 12 December 1921. Besides the choir, a tamburica ensemble was also active in the Adria Society for a few years. Its drama section was also quite successful. In short: in September 1927 the rich Slovenian cultural life in Barcola was interrupted violently. All these efforts were not restored until the liberation in May 1945. Milan Pahor

div.div: Med ustanovami, ki so v začetku 20. stoletja zapustile vidno in bogato sled v Nabrežini, velja poudariti pomen Javne ljudske knjižnice. Pot društva se začenja 10. januarja 1906, ko so se domačini zbrali na javnem shodu v vasi. Zbrani pobudniki so na shodu izvolili pripravljalni odbor, ki mu je predsedoval Hinko Holler. Pripravili so statut društva ter sprožili nabiralno akcijo za denar in knjige. V dveh mesecih so zbrali okrog 200 knjig. Ustanovni občni zbor je bil 21. aprila 1906 v prostorih gostilne Ignaca Tanceta v Nabrežini. Društvo je takrat štelo 43 članov. Izvolili so novo vodstvo: Predsednik Ivan Skrjanec, podpredsednik Hinko Holler, blagajnik Rado Medič, tajnik Ivan Kosmina, odborniki Josip Frančeškin, Lambert Pertot, Ivan Caharija, Franc Nemec. Knjižnica je imela svoje prostore v stavbi Konsumnega društva v Nabrežini. Odprta je bila dvakrat tedensko: ob nedeljah opoldne in ob sredah zvečer. Poleg upravljanja in vodenja knjižnice je društvo gojilo še predavateljsko dejavnost ter skrbelo za družabnost s prirejanjem plesov in veselic. Leta 1911 so izdali manjšo knjižico z naslovom V spomin petletnice 1906-1911. Pred prvo vojno je deloval še amaterski dramski krožek v okviru društva. Izbruh vojne je ohromil delovanje. V začetku leta 1920 je knjižnica ponovno zaživela, knjižni fond je štel okrog 1000 enot. Razmere pa so se spremenile, saj je Nabrežina bila v kraljevini Italiji, avstroogrska monarhija je razpadla po prvi vojni vihri, nastopilo je obdobje fašističnega režima in nasilja nad slovenskim prebivalstvom. Za knjižnico so se začeli težki časi. Najprej, v letu 1923, je moralo vodstvo med člane sprejeti pripadnike fašistične stranke. Leta 1926 je v prostore knjižnice vdrla fašistična škvadra, ki je opustošila društvene prostore. Knjige in časopise ter ves društveni arhiv so zmetali na glavni trg v vasi, kjer so vse skupaj demonstrativno zažgali. 19. julija 1927 je bila Javna ljudska knjižnica v Nabrežini razpuščena s posebnim odlokom. Milan Pahor

The importance of the Public People's Library (Javna ljudska knjižnica) among the institutions with a visible and rich legacy in Aurisina should be emphasised. The activities of this society began on 10 January 1906, when the locals gathered at the public meeting in the village. At the meeting the initiators elected a preparatory committee, presided over by Hinko Holler. They outlined the statute of the new society and started an action in order to collect funds and books. Around 200 books were collected in two months. The founding general meeting took place on 21 April 1906 in Ignac Tance's tavern in Aurisina. At the time the society had 43 members. A new leadership was elected: president Ivan Skrjanec, vice president Hinko Holler, treasurer Rado Medič, secretary Ivan Kosmina, board members Josip Frančeškin, Lambert Pertot, Ivan Caharija and Franc Nemec. The library's facilities were located in the building of the Nabrežina Consumer Society. It was open twice per week: Sundays at noon and Wednesdays in the evening. Besides managing the library, the society also focused on lectures and took care of social activities by organising dances and festivities. In 1911 the society published a small booklet entitled At the Fifth Anniversary 1906-1911. Before World War I an amateur drama club was also active in the context of the society. World War I brought the efforts of this society to a halt. In the beginning of 1920 the library became active again and its book collection now consisted of around 1000 units. However, the circumstances had changed: after World War I the Austro Hungarian Monarchy had dissolved, Aurisina had been annexed to the Kingdom of Italy, and the period of the fascist regime and violence against the Slovenian population had begun. Difficult times began for the library. First – in 1923 – the leadership had to accept adherents of the fascist party as members of the library. In 1926 fascists broke into the library and wreaked havoc in the society's facilities. They threw the books, newspapers and archives into the main square and burned them all. On 19 July 1927 the Public People's Library in Aurisina was dissolved with a special decree. Milan Pahor

Dramatični krožek je v Gorici deloval v dvajsetih letih 20. stoletja, v nemirnih časih fašističnega režima na Primorskem med dvema svetovnima vojnama. V nekajletnem delovanju je kar trikrat spremenil naziv. Dramatični krožek je bil ustanovljen 20. avgusta 1922. Do leta 1924 je deloval kot Dramatični krožek, na občnem zboru dne 5. oktobra 1924 v Trgovskem domu v Gorici je spremenil ime v Dramatično društvo. V letu 1925 se je preimenoval v Dramsko društvo v Gorici. To ime je ostalo do nasilne ukinitve v letu 1927. Takrat je več slovenskih društev spreminjalo imena, ker so lahko na ta način nadaljevala z isto dejavnostjo, čeprav je formalno nastalo novo društvo. Odbor krožka oziroma društva se je sestajal na sedežu Zveze slovenskih prosvetnih društev v Gorici. V zvezo so se včlanili 15. novembra 1923 in v njej ostali vse do razpustitve v letu 1927. Občasno se je vodstvo sestajalo tudi na sedežu Pevskega in glasbenega društva v Gorici. Društva so sodelovala in si pomagala v tistih težkih časih za slovensko kulturo, besedo in jezik. Vaje so potekale ob sredah v prostorih Trgovskega doma, kjer je društvo tudi imelo svoje glavne nastope z naštudiranimi igrami, veliko pa so tudi nastopali v okolici Gorice. Imeli so redne gledališke sezone z vrsto iger, enodejank ipd. Ob glavnem odboru je deloval še veselični odsek, saj so skrbeli za plese, miklavževe večere in silvestrovanja. Prva tri leta je Dramatični krožek oziroma društvo vodila kot predsednica Marija (Marica) Rutar, nato je od leta 1925 dalje bil predsednik Avgust Kozman, ki je mnogokrat tudi režiral igre v društvu. Vse skupaj se je zaključilo z nasilno razpustitvijo v letu 1927.Milan Pahor

The Drama Club (Dramatični krožek) in Gorizia was active in the 1920s, in the restless times of the fascist regime in the Littoral region between the two world wars. During the several years of its existence it changed its name as many as three times. The Drama Club was founded on 20 August 1922. Until 1924 it kept operating as the Drama Club, but at the general meeting on 5 October 1924 in the Commerce Hall in Gorizia it was renamed as the Drama Society (Dramatično društvo). In 1925 it was renamed as the Gorizia Drama Society (Dramsko društvo v Gorici). This name remained until its forced abolishment in 1927. At that time many Slovenian societies changed their names in order to keep pursuing the same activities, even if formally a new society was formed. The Drama Society circle would meet at the head office of the Association of Slovenian Educational Societies in Gorizia. The Drama Society became a member of this Association on 15 November 1923 and remained a member until its dissolution in 1927. Periodically the leadership would also meet in the office of the Choir and Music Society in Gorizia. The societies worked together and assisted each other to preserve Slovenian culture, literature and language in those difficult times. Rehearsals took place every Wednesday in the facilities of the Commerce Hall (Trgovski dom), where the Drama Society also staged the main plays it studied, while it also performed frequently in the Gorizia surroundings. It had regular theatre seasons with a range of plays, one act plays, etc. The festivity section, operating besides the management committee, was responsible for the organisation of dances, St. Nicholas evenings and New Year's Eve celebrations. For the first three years the president of the Drama Club or Drama Society was Marija (Marica) Rutar. Since 1925 it was presided over by Avgust Kozman, who also often directed its plays. It all ended with the forced abolishment in 1927. Milan Pahor
